alendit commented on a change in pull request #2875: ARROW-3656: [C++] Allow whitespace in numeric CSV fields
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2875#discussion_r229658276
 
 

 ##########
 File path: cpp/src/arrow/csv/converter.cc
 ##########
 @@ -44,6 +44,13 @@ Status GenericConversionError(const std::shared_ptr<DataType>& type, const uint8
   return Status::Invalid(ss.str());
 }
 
+inline bool IsWhitespace(uint8_t c) {
+  if (ARROW_PREDICT_TRUE(c > 0x20)) {
 
 Review comment:
   Maybe `c > ' ` or even `c > ' ' && c > '\t'` here to make it more explicit? The last one should get optimized to a single comparison anyway.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
Pandas allows whitespace before and after numbers in CSV files, but Arrow doesn't:
{code:python}
>>> s = b"a,b,c\n12 , 34 , 56\n"
>>> pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(s))
    a   b   c
0  12  34  56
>>> csv.read_csv(io.BytesIO(s)).to_pandas()
        a        b       c
0  b'12 '  b' 34 '  b' 56'
{code}
fields.summary: [C++] Allow whitespace in numeric CSV fields

comments.body: [~wesmckinn], do you think this is a commun occurrence?

What about

```

s1 = b"a,b,c\n0,1,2\n 0 , 1, 2"

s2 = b"a,b,c\n 0 , 1 , 2 \n0,1,2"

```

Seems to me that there's no correct answer if no schema is provided.

Well, Pandas handles that one as follows:
{code:python}
>>> s = b"a,b,c\n0,1,2\n 0 , 1, 2"                                                                                                                                  
>>> pd.read_csv(io.BytesIO(s))                                                                                                                                      
   a  b  c
0  0  1  2
1  0  1  2
{code}

What I'm trying to say is that there's no correct answer, both cases are lossy (one row is integers, the other is bytes) what changes is the order. I'd expect that most csv readers will infer the schema (types) from the first non-header row.

It's not a good idea to infer only from the first row, because of nulls or other false positives.

Indeed there's no absolutely correct answer, but type inference should make a best effort to give satisfying results on real-world data. Right now we don't allow passing a schema to impose fixed types, though that's something we should add.
It's quite common to have whitespace
